No joke. "Aiplex Software Private Limited" has been falsely flagging any video related to Spider-Man on smaller channels. They claim these videos are using footage from No Way Home but that is not the case. Original works, such a parody I wrote, filmed, and produced have been taken down for "pirating" footage from the newest film. Seems that has been the only reason they use to take down content, irregardless of what the video is. "Bully Maguire" meme channels have been a high target from these assholes lately, and their videos, or even channels in worst cases, are terminated for "using NWH footage." These guys aren't even a legitimate company, and YouTube has refused to get involved. It's one thing to have this kind of content taken down by copyright owners (such as Sony, Disney, or Insomniac because even GAMEPLAY footage has been taken down), but Aiplex owns NOTHING. They aren't a real company with any real legal standing to do this to anyone. I made a video detailing the entire situation in-depth, which Aiplex even tried to take down, even though it's just me talking into a camera with no background music. We need bigger YouTubers to speak out about this. YouTube refuses to get involved, even when faced with a petition that bears 25,000 signatures to look into Aiplex. This "Nintendo" situation is only a small piece of a larger puzzle. So many small channels are needlessly at stake because YouTube allows assholes like these guys to just claim content whenever they want.

Think about it, it's a win-win situation as far as they're concerned: Nintendo gets the flack and nobody would think to question it due to Nintendo's past actions, while everyone they knuckle over deals with the fallout of Youtube's broken claim system and they can watch the world burn as a result of their actions.

Honestly, I'm going through this right now with YouTube.

I uploaded a review of Evil Bong in 2012, and one of the many "AdRev" entities claimed it, saying I used the material they owned. Specifically, the 13 Nights of Elvira Evil Bong episode. However, said episode was not released until December 2014.

I disputed, as you do, and they rejected. I appealed, and now they're aiming to give my channel a copyright strike for my trouble.

As I do movie reviews almost exclusively and use a lot of copyrighted content in my videos, I'm more than used to the dispute process and the fact that fair use or not, YouTube refuses to ever side with the creator. It's guilty until proven innocent, but this claim was so ridiculous - that I used copyrighted material that didn't even exist yet when I produced my video - I actually went to YouTube themselves.

Or team youtube on Twitter anyway... it's the best most of us can do.

After explaining the situation, they came back and told me that AdRev is perfectly in the right because even though I used footage from Evil Bong, a movie owned by Full Moon Features, as AdRev are dealing with the digital rights of an episode of Elvira that licensed the movie, through some digital dark magic AdRev are now the rightful copyright owners of Evil Bong and are freely allowed to strike me as they see fit and I just have to deal with it.

Since then I have been trying to get in contact with Full Moon themselves to see what they think about it, but unfortunately it has been eight years since I last worked with them and my contact has evidently moved on and his e-mail no longer works. Trying to bring this up to the company via their merch sales support staff has been less than fruitful.

I'm certain I'll fight through this copyright strike just as I have the 10+ others I've received over the years, but the fact that the system is so broken that someone can claim copyright for material they don't own, based on a claim that isn't even possible to be true from the most basic understanding of how time works, and STILL I'm just gonna have to deal with it and hopefully not lose my channel? Really?
@TheJimmyCartel Lmao

@RosePhoenix True, but I have dealt directly with Full Moon in the past - and I did get automated copyright strikes from them before. The owner there was listed as Full Moon Features.

I can point to a time this certainly happened to me in the past, fraudulently. Heck, anyone here can test this method out: Upload some public domain stuff! Companies like AdRev love throwing that into the content ID system to claim it until the end of time. One of the reasons I stopped doing public domain movie riffs as a supporter reward... Of note, Little Dot Studios claimed my riff of The Ghoul (1936) which was not only in the public domain, but had a long, well documented history of how and when it got into the public domain. Presenting LDS with this information... they gave my channel a copyright strike.

They're still operating to this day, of course. You can find employee reviews of them, where their own staff feel horrible for these kinds of business practices. They believe it's legal, but they also find it repugnant.

Cus what is said here according to this article that Shigeru Miyamoto Approves Of People Uploading Gameplay Videos said" , I think it’s good that there’s a variety of ways to enjoy things. If these claims were done manually that would take a hell of a long time. Here's how long it would take

I timed how long it would take an average person to fill out a copyright claim and found it to be about two minutes per video if you include selecting the next video and opening another claim and whatnot.

3500 videos x 2 minutes per video = 7000 minutes in total
7000 / 60 = 116 hours in total
116 / 24 = 4 days and 20 hours (bruh) in total

If this was one person it would have taken almost 5 solid days to claim each one individually.

Furthermore if you were to split it over 2 hours per day 5 days a week (Which is about the most any sane person could take) it means it would take 23 weeks to complete, almost 6 months.

In the case that this is a group, it can't be a large group or their presence and intents could be leaked. Only a small amount of people could be trusted. Let's say this is 5 people.

3,500 videos / 5 people = 700 videos each
700 x 2 = 1400 minutes per person
1400 / 60 = 23 hours and 20 minutes per person in total to claim 3,500 videos individually.
Applying the same maths (Rule Britannia) as before:

23 hours and 20 minutes spread over 2 hours a day for 5 days a week means that it would be done in approximately 1 week and 5 days.

The biggest problem with the Lechmere theory is that the “research” began with the assumption that Lechmere was the Ripper and then the research went backwards to try and fit Lechmere into the murders. Furthermore, even doing this, there is zero strong evidence against him.

The biggest thing some people claim is that Lechmere lied to the police and gave them a false name. Did he? Sure. But interestingly enough, he also gave them his correct address and his place of employment. So it’s more likely that he was commonly using the name Cross because it makes no sense to give a false name but still tell the police where you live.

There was one witness who saw Lechmere standing over the body. Robert Paul’s own testimony was that Nichols body was very cold. It takes 10 to 20 minutes for a body to get cold. The “evidence” against Lechmere claims he was caught in the act or immediately afterward.

Another piece of evidence is that he was a local Whitechapel resident and most people believed the Ripper was local. Fine and dandy. There were thousands of other local residents and most Ripper suspects fit this description. Also, Nichols body was found on his route to work. Well, duh. He wasn’t going to find the body on his way to work if it wasn’t on his route. This is just lazy reasoning.

Other than Elizabeth Stride, all the victims were on his route to work. And of course Stride was murdered close to the house that Lechmere’s mother lived. So one night, on the way to visit his mom, he decides to murder someone. I mean, why go over to mom’s house if you haven’t strangled a lady before? If Lechmere was such a impulsive murderer as to do this, why did he stop murdering and live for decades longer?

Edward Stow “The police at the time were looking for some sort of special individual. But most crimes turn out to be someone quite ordinary. He [Cross] walked past every single murder scene on his way to work. He is the best suspect so far."

The above paragraph is one of the more amusing things I have come across in regards to Lechmere. Stow claims that the police were looking for some sort of special individual and that’s why they didn’t suspect Lechmere. This makes no sense because the police were NOT looking for some sort of special individual. Nichols was the first canonical ripper murder. Her body was found on August 31. At the time, they were not looking for a special person that fit a profile of a serial killer named Jack the Ripper or a serial killer at all. It would be weeks and more murders before the police began looking for a “special individual.”

Everything about Lechmere is circumstantial. But the biggest piece of evidence, that being the false name, is completely negated by him giving the correct home address and place of work. It is highly unlikely he was the Ripper.

This isn't the first and only case of YouTube's copyright system being abused. "Aiplex Software Private Limited" has also been falsely flagging any video related to Spider-Man on smaller channels. They claim these videos are using footage from No Way Home but that is not the case. Original works, such a parody I wrote, filmed, and produced have been taken down for "pirating" footage from the newest film. Seems that has been the only reason they use to take down content, irregardless of what the video is. "Bully Maguire" meme channels have been a high target from these assholes lately, and their videos, or even channels in worst cases, are terminated for "using NWH footage." These guys aren't even a legitimate company, and YouTube has refused to get involved. It's one thing to have this kind of content taken down by copyright owners (such as Sony, Disney, or Insomniac because even GAMEPLAY footage has been taken down), but Aiplex owns NOTHING. They aren't a real company with any real legal standing to do this to anyone. I made a video detailing the entire situation in-depth, which Aiplex even tried to take down, even though it's just me talking into a camera with no background music. Charlie, we need bigger YouTubers to speak out about this. YouTube refuses to get involved, even when faced with a petition that bears 25,000 signatures to look into Aiplex. This "Nintendo" situation is only a small piece of a larger puzzle. So many small channels are needlessly at stake.

This isn't the first and only case of YouTube's copyright system being abused. "Aiplex Software Private Limited" has also been falsely flagging any video related to Spider-Man on smaller channels. They claim these videos are using footage from No Way Home but that is not the case. Original works, such a parody I wrote, filmed, and produced have been taken down for "pirating" footage from the newest film. Seems that has been the only reason they use to take down content, irregardless of what the video is. "Bully Maguire" meme channels have been a high target from these assholes lately, and their videos, or even channels in worst cases, are terminated for "using NWH footage." These guys aren't even a legitimate company, and YouTube has refused to get involved. It's one thing to have this kind of content taken down by copyright owners (such as Sony, Disney, or Insomniac because even GAMEPLAY footage has been taken down), but Aiplex owns NOTHING. They aren't a real company with any real legal standing to do this to anyone. I made a video detailing the entire situation in-depth, which Aiplex even tried to take down, even though it's just me talking into a camera with no background music. We need bigger YouTubers like Charlie to speak out about this. YouTube refuses to get involved, even when faced with a petition that bears 25,000 signatures to look into Aiplex. This "Nintendo" situation is only a small piece of a larger puzzle. So many small channels are needlessly at stake.

Original works, such a parody I wrote, filmed, and produced have been taken down for "pirating" footage from the newest film. "Bully Maguire" meme channels have been a high target from these assholes lately, and their videos, or even channels in worst cases, are terminated for "using NWH footage." These guys aren't even a legitimate company, and YouTube has refused to get involved. It's one thing to have this kind of content taken down by copyright owners (such as Sony, Disney, or Insomniac because even GAMEPLAY footage has been taken down), but Aiplex owns NOTHING. They aren't a real company with any real legal standing to do this to anyone. I made a video detailing the entire situation in-depth, which Aiplex even tried to take down, even though it's just me talking into a camera with no background music. We need bigger YouTubers to speak out about this. YouTube refuses to get involved, even when faced with a petition that bears 25,000 signatures to look into Aiplex. These channels rarely interact with each other as far as I know, and a rivalry makes little sense considering many of these channels cater to slightly different audiences, Gilva uploaded the raw music, many other channels upload extended versions.

The saddest thing is, Gilva probably had the LARGEST stockpile of Nintendo music on Youtube, it's a shame seeing the channel go, especially with the knowledge that some of the tracks may never be uploaded again for a very, very long time. I would believe a rivalry if music channels were competitive in even the slightest, but Gilva had a "dead" or better, a slightly inactive channel, rarely uploading for they had already uploaded the majority of content they wanted to or had. Gilva wasn't competition to begin with.
